div.p: ❧ A LITEL TREATISE ageynste the mutterynge of some papistis in corners. ❧
LONDINI IN AEDIBVS
THO. BERTHELETI.
AN. M. D. XXXIIII.
CVM PRIVILEGIO.

div.head: TREATISE
div.p:
FOr so moche that somme controuersie, at the fyrste sight of certayne bokes, of late put forthe concernynge the bysshoppe of Rome, called the pope, rose amonge the people, some meruaylynge, that we shulde so sodeynely relynquysshe and forsake that custome, that had so longe continued, and some were so blynded, that they thought it shulde be ageynste our feythe, to forsake the pope (but I thynke they, that so supposed, dyd put more their trust in the pope, then in Christe.) And the moste parte of that sorte made none other reason but this: That if we do well nowe, thus to forsake the pope, then all our forefathers dyd amisse, and so dyd we also, tylle this presente tyme, which were vnder obedience and subiection of the byshoppe of Rome, named pope: and they beleued, that he had auctoritie and power to make lawes,
& to bynde & leuse what, & whom he wold. This was the greattest reson that many men made: whiche I suppose they dyd eyther of affection, orels throughe ignoraunce. I haue thought it therfore very expedient to labour for my power, to answere and partlye to satisfie their doubtes, to the intent that after they knowe the truthe, they shulde be ashamed so to clatter in corners ageinst it, and also (all thynges knowne) against theyr owne profite. And shortly to answere vnto theyr fore made reason, I saye that if our forefathers dyd beleue the pope to haue had suche a power and auctorytie gyuen hym by god, that he myght make lawes, and order all mattiers and businessis of Christendome, after his owne luste & pleasure (like as verye many of theym haue done this. viii. C. yeres and more) then were they blynd and in a wrong beleue, whiche thynge I thynke verely
they dyd not, but that al our fore fathers, as many as were lerned and wyse, knewe it for certeyne, that all suche auctorytie and power, as the pope had, more then al other byshops or ouer and vppon the same, was not immediately gyuen hym by god, but he had it granted him by kynges and princis, and the consente of men, or els came by it by wronge vsurpation and tirrannye. For the same fathers knewe righte well, that by the lawes of god, all bysshoppes were, and yet nowe be in power and auctoritie equall, and that the byshop of Rome in al poyntes of our fayth, and belefe is subiecte vnto holye scripture and the generall counsell, and may by the auctoritie of the same as wel be deposed for sufficient causes, as any other byshoppe may: And this right welle maye they knowe that rede suche holy fathers, as bothe for lyfe and lernynge haue ben euer moste approued
in Christis church, as saynt Ciprian, saint Hierom, saint Ambrose, seint Augustine, with other lyke. The whiche thyng surely coulde neuer haue bene tru, yf that the pope (as som papistes both write & sai) be heed of the church & may do in erth what he wyl, & al be it that many good simple & vnlerned folke haue thought the gret vsurped power of the bishop of Rome, to haue ben giuen to hym by the lawe of god, (hervnto induced by such as sekinge their owne profyt, in the mayntenāce therof, haue ben accoūted lerned) yet was not this mater vnto them dānable nor they therfore so moch to be blamed, but rather suche as haue seduced them herin. But this not withstandynge, to sey truely in this matter, that is not so moche to be regarded, what our fore faders haue done, as what they oughte to do. For as their good exāples must be folowed, so theyr yuel muste be fled. Almighty Eze. 20. god, by the mouthe of his prophette
Ezechiel, saythe: Walke not in your fathers rules, neither kepe their iudgemētis, ne be not poluted with their idols: for I am youre lorde god, but walke ye in my cōmandemētis (seyth he) and kepe my iudgemētis, and fulfyl 1. Cor. 11. them. &c. Also sainct Paule, one of our best fore fathers, biddith vs folowe him, euyn as he folowid Christ. Marke nowe. He saythe, euyn as he folowed Christe: meanynge, that in no case we shulde folowe hym, where as he swarued from Christe. Wherfore if any of our fore fathers, of ignorance, or for their owne glorie or lucre, haue brought any custome in to Christis churche, contrarie to truthe and his holy doctrine: we oughte of duetie (refusinge suche erroneous custome) to folowe the truthe. For if sainct Paule hym selfe (whiche with a feruent zele kepte his fathers tradicions and lawes, ye and fiersely persecutid the transgressors of the same) had walked styll in his fathers steppes,
and hadde not forsaken them to come to the truthe: he had neuer ben saued. Herunto accordeth sayncte Augustins wordis, in his secōd boke intitled De unico baptismo, Truthe ones knowen (saith he) custome must giue place to the truthe. For who douteth that custome ought to gyue place to the truthe ones publyshed? Nor let no man preferre Custome afore reson and truthe: for alweys Reason and truthe putteth custome out of place.

To this sayenge of saint Augustine C • si cōsuetud. di. 8. agreith saint Gregori, writing thus: If percase thou leyest ageynst vs custome, it muste be regarded, that our Io. 8. lorde seyth: I am the wey, I am the truthe, I am the lyfe. He sayde not, that I am olde vsage and Custome, but the Truthe. And certaynely (as sainct Cyprian sayth) euery custome, be it neuer so olde, neuer so cōmon & general, is to be vtterly forsaken for the truthe sake: and that vsage, that
is contrarie to the truthe, is vtterly to be destroyed. Wherfore not withstandinge any vsage or custome, it is laufull, and standeth very well with goddis worde, the truthe ones knowen, to withdrawe our obedience frō the byshop of Rome: by ouer moche obedience vnto whom of longe seson we haue ben seducid and ledde out of the right wey, and haue alowed many of his vices for high vertues.

Herof saincte Gregorie warneth vs 2. q. 7. c. Admonendi. to take heede, sayenge: Subiectes ought to be admonished, not to be obedient vnto their prelatis more thā is expediente, lest whiles they endeuoir them selfes to be obediēt to men more than nede is, they shulde be cōpelled to reuerence, alowe, & preyse theyr vices.

Se here, saint Gregori aloweth not suche obedience, wherby prelatis vices shulde be meynteyned. And surely in suche thinges, wherin they opēly
sclaunder the churche, it standeth right wel with the lawe of god, openly to reproue them: and from this the bishop of Rome, all though he were ten tymes called Pope, is not except: orlels we muste nedes graunte, that saint Paule did amisse, whiche reproued Peter (that is callid the prince of Gal. 2. the apostols) euen in the face, that is to sey, before the holle congregacion of the churche. If saynt Paule dyd thus to saint Peter, that was instituted by Christe hym selfe, and whanne saincte Peter erred not in his feythe, but for eatinge of meatis prohibite to the iewes, whiche was but a ceremonie, and at that tyme hauynge no strengthe: howe moche more thanne ought the pope to be reproued of all good christen people, the whiche beinge chosen and institutid by men, without myracle or reuelacion (I wyll not sey ofte tymes by symonie) dothe not only fle from the folowing of our
sauiour Iesu Christe, and his blessed apostoll Peter, whose successour the pope and papistis seye that he is, but also he excludeth clene Christe with his mekenes, pouertie, and obediēce, expressed in the holy euāgelistis, and for Christe he wolbe knowen, and for Christis lawes, he bryngethe forthe lawes and traditions of his owne diuisyng, the whiche wollen hym to be lorde and syre ouer all, to be stronge, riche, and myghty, and that all men shulde be obedient to his wyll.

And all thoughe some bringe in, in this place here, this texte, Credo sanctam Ecclesiam catholicam, it can litel help their argument. For I suppose, that there was neuer wise man so farre ouer seen, neither of our forefathers, nor of those that be in our tyme, that beleued, that the Pope is the catholyke holy Churche: but they knewe well, that he is but a membre therof, and the childe of our mother the holy
churche (if he be a true christen man) and brother to euery christen man.

And for a playne proffe that this is true, our sauiour Iesu Christ taught vs al to praye one prayour: Our father matt. 6. that arte in heuen. &c. Then seinge that we all haue but one father, whiche is in heuen, and one mother the holy churche in erthe, it is manifeste and clere to all the worlde, that the pope and we be al bretherne (if he be a true christen man.) And then seinge the Pope is oure brother, why shulde not he haue & abyde brotherly correction, accordinge to the lawe of the gospell, where Christe saythe: If Mat. 18. Luc. 17. thy brother offende the, correcte hym betwene the and hym alone.

And if some wyl yet sey (supposinge that he hath suche auctoritie of god, as he presumeth to haue) that ye pope ought not to be thus layde vnto, and so sharply constrained to shewe to the worlde, what auctorite he hath to do,
as he longe hath done, as for example, to dispēce in any case ageynst the lawe of god: then the apostols and Act 11. brethern ought not in Iudea to haue layde it to saint Peters charge, when he was come to Hierusalem, and constrayne hym to shewe the reason why he viseted and taught Cornelius the gentile, with whome by the iewes lawes he ought not to haue cōpanied.

And therfore let no man thynke, but that our forefathers toke the pope alweye to be a man, a synner, & suche a one as might well erre, & suche a one as ought moche rather to be examined of his lyfe and state, then the holy apostel Peter for viseting of Cornelius: yea & our fore fathers neuer toke hym for any other but suche one as might wel and ought to be refourmed, corrected, ye and clene deposed and put downe, as many popis haue ben in tymes paste, by kyngis & princis, wherof no man is ignorant, that
hath redde the stories that intreate of the businesse of Christendome. And therfore no man ought to marueile & mutturre in corners, as thoughe we shulde nowe attempt a thinge in Englande, whiche our fore fathers had neuer attempted in tymes paste.

For vndoubtedly all men, that were before tyme, whiche were wise & well lerned, and that knewe Christe & his doctrine, and that willed Christe and his doctrine to reigne, & to be knowē & folowid of al christen people, did abhorre the pompose and worldly state of the pope, and his tradicions, that he made to vpholde the same: & they sparid not to speke and write ageynst his abhominable abusions: and for that cause they were alwey put either to silence orels to dethe, by the great princis of the worlde, at the instance of the pope & his papistis, of whome there is spronge vp to great a numbre in euery region and coūtrey: and
al that was by reason that the noble princis them selfe were vnlernid, and coude not iuge in suche matters, but they gaue alwey credēce to the falce, subtyle, and slye persuasions of the pope and his bolsterers. But nowe thankes be to almyghtie god, frome whom cometh al goodnes, the father Iac. 1. of lightis, the princis hartis beginne to be lyghted with the knowledge of Christis doctrine, and they begynne to perceyue, what wey this wily wat hath walked all this lōge while: and what great hurte, wronge, & oppression they haue sufferedde: And howe moche more iniury he entended to do to our mooste gratious soueraygne lorde the kinge, whose highnes, with his moste honorable counsaile, haue bene constrayned, by theyr great labour and study, to trie out the truthe. For if they them selfe hadde not, by theyr diligente studie, sought out his false fraude, the popishe forme shuld
neuer haue ben refourmedde, nor it shulde neuer haue ben knowne, that the pope is but a byshop in his owne diocese, and that he ought to preache and teche the people, & that he ought not to occupie lordeshyppes of this worlde, but vtterly to refuse al worldly honoure, delite, or pleasure, in ryches and renome, as Christe and his blessed apostols did, whom he ought to folowe.

¶ AND farthermore to sey, that the kingis highnes is displeasid, bicause the Pope wyll not folowe his gracis mynde in his moste weyghtye cause: is a sayenge bothe false and vntrue, and it besemeth no louynge subiecte so to surmise. For the verie truthe is, that his grace hath of longe season vtterly refused the popis iudgement in his great and waighty cause, and not nowe sodaynely, as these men imagin: and hath cōmitted the handlynge therof vnto all the beste lerned
vniuersities, and to all the beste lerned men in christendome, as vnto suche that for theyr lerninge coude best iudge in goddis lawe, wheron his gracis cause holly hangeth, neuer intendynge to stande to the popis iudgement, onlesse he iudged the same, that the lawe of god wolde hym herin to do, and that not bycause of his power and auctorite, but for the truthes sake. To the whiche lerned men and vniuersities determination (as a prince moste iuste and vertuous) he alwey offered hym selfe to stande and abyde, and accordynge therto hath nowe prosecuted his cause. whiche thinge ye maye well witte his grace wolde neuer haue doone, excepte he hadde seen the lawe of god clerely on his side: Nor so many vniuersities & excellente lerned men, wolde neuer haue so determined, excepte it hadde stande styffely with the lawe of god.

If his gracis matter had not ben, as
afore is sayde: it had ben farre more easye for his highnes, if he had rekenid the popis auctorite sufficient therfore, to haue shortly corrupted hym, beinge but one man, the which thing is easy to be done: then with so great and importable charges, and with so longe tracte of tyme, to haue sought for the truthe in so many vniuersitis, in whiche are so many men of diuers opinions and wittes. AND accordinge to the truthe, thus wel and orderly knowen, his gracis cause hath ben by sufficiēt auctoritie of the churche of Englande, fully ended and determined: wherin no man ought to doubte, the holy goste to be resident, as well as at Rome: as ryghte well maye appere by the epistole of Affricane councell, writen vnto pope Celestine.

¶ AND yet for further contentacion of al men, so that none either lerned or vnlerned, shulde be with his gracis
moste iuste cause and doinge herin offended, consydering that a great parte of the worlde did beleue, as many yet dothe (other wyse then treuthe is) that the pope bi goddis lawe hath auctoritie aboue all other bishoppes, to here and determine causes within this realme of Englande: his highnes attemperinge hym selfe to the infyrmitie of the multitude, where he myghte lefully haue withstanded by his owne auctoritie, the popis vsurped iurisdiction (wherby he wolde haue enforced our soueraygne to the breche of the lawe of god) and might right wel vnto hym haue sayde: we muste rather obeye god then men: he Act. 5. hath frome all suche vsurpacion and other iniuries, wherwith the Poope wolde, if he had bene suffered, haue aggreued his highnesse: Frome all these (I sey) he hath appeled vnto the generall councell, and is herin (lyke a tru christened and a good catholike
prince) very well contented to abyde suche determination, as the sayd coūcelle nexte to be assembled in our sauioure Iesu Christe, shall ordeyne.

Nothinge herby doubtinge the iustenes of his cause, so manifest to al the worlde: nor herby bringinge his said iuste cause, all redy well and sufficiently determined, into controuersie and new sute: the whiche to do is not his gracis purpose.

¶ AND admitte that the pope had as great auctoritie, as he vsurpeth, and as the papistis wold fayne beare men in hande that he hath: yet coude he lette no man to appele from hym: for that were clerely ageynst the lawe of Nature, whiche is not contrarie to the lawe diuine. For then a man beinge harmed or wrongid by the pope, eyther in bodye, membres, or fame, shulde not in this case be holpen nor eased. And if it be leful for any christen man, what so euer he be, to appele
to the councell generall, as it is in dede: then what iniurie dothe the pope to our souerayne, whiche dothe all that he can to driue hym from his appele? Yea what iniurie intendeth he to all men, whiche labourynge to make oure prince and kynge a president, woll in tyme to come, suffre no man to appele frō his cursed courte?

¶ AND though it were so, that the pope (admittynge hym to haue suche auctoritie) dyd to no man, but accordynge to the wyll and worde of god: yet he can not chose, but is bounde to shewe the reason why he so dothe, before the Churche, whiche the general Councell, gethered in the holy goste, dothe represent: lyke as saincte Peter in Hierusalem, where the churche was, dyd mekely make answere vnto Act. 11. those that were of the circumcision, whiche disputed ageynste hym, sayenge: Why hast thou entred in amonge, and eaten and dronke with
those that be not circumcised? To this the holy apostoll dyd not onely, humblye and mekelye answerynge, shewe them the cause why he dyd it: but also he gaue a lesson to all them, that shulde folowe hym, humblie to do like wise: Be ye redy alwey, sayth
〈…〉 Pe
•… i. 3. he, to answer & satisfie euery mā that asketh you a reason of your feythe & hope, with mekenes and reuerence.

¶ BY al these reasons it is to you euident, that our souerayne hath now righte good cause to open vnto you, what maner of persone the byshoppe of Rome is, the whiche after manye monitions, refuseth at length to here the churche, that is to wytte the Generall councell, but woll hym selfe be iudge at his owne pleasure: he forcethe not for the doctrine of Christe, nor for the example of Peter, nor his teachinge, but sayth he woll be obeyed, and accordynge to his lawes, the whiche be none other but his owne
wyl, he wol haue vs do.

¶ MORE ouer, if any papiste wyll come yet forthe and tell you, that the pope may do what he wyl, and maye bynde and leuse what he lysteth here on erthe, bicause Christe sayde to Peter, Matth. 6. I wol gyue to the, the keys of the kyngedome of heuen: lette hym not therwith blynde and deceyue you.

For saincte Augustine, spekynge of these keys in his fyrste boke De doctrina christiana, sayth thus: Those keyes he gaue to his churche, that what so euer the churche wolde leuse in erthe, shulde be lowsed in heuen: and what so euer the churche shulde bynde in erthe, shulde be bounde in heuen.
Nowe it is wel proued to you before, that the pope is nother the churche, nor the heed therof, but a membre (if he be a christen man) and the childe of our mother the holy churche.

¶ AND ferther if any wyll yet telle you, that at the leeste wyse the Pope
hath the keye of diuine knoweledge, wherof Christe speketh Luce. xi. whether he so haue or no, ye shal perceyue it thus: The glose seythe, that this keye is the humilitie of Christe, the whiche who so hath, hath the gaate open to the vnderstandinge of scripture. Nowe take heede and se whether the Pope haue this humilytie: Christe the very sonne of god, dydde Philip. 2. humble hym selfe euyn to the veray dethe, yea to the shamefull dethe of the crosse: The pope (ye se very well) woll be exalted aboue all other, in so moche that kynges, princis, dukes, and lordes muste kneele to hym and kysse his feete, and do to hym all the honoure and worshyppe, that can be deuised in this worlde. Wherfore it appereth playnely, that he hath not this keye of knoweledge, whiche is Christis humilitie.

¶ ALSO this keye of knoweledge may be taken and called the feythe,
accordynge as Esaye, the prophette Esaie. 7. saythe: Except ye woll beleue, ye can not vnderstande. Nowe marke wel whether the Pope haue this keye of feythe or no. Christe saythe, that he Mat. 17. that hath as moche feythe as a lytell mustarde sede, shall be able to commande mountaynes to remoue from one place to an other: and ther shuld be nothynge impossible vnto hym. And agayne Christe sayth: All thynges Mar. 19. are possible to him that beleueth. And agayne yet he saythe in an other place: He that beleueth in me, shall Io. 14. do the warkes that I do, and greatter then those. This is to vnderstād, that if the pope were ioynid to Christ in his feythe, as the apostols were, he shulde be able to do lyke as the apostols dyd, that is to wytte, by his preachynge of the gospell truely, he shulde conuerte and turne nations of mysbeleuynge people, to the feythe of Iesu Christe. Whiche thynge all
the worlde seeth playnly he doth not: but by his pryde, his tyrannye, and mooste greuous exactions he hathe and dothe (I feare me) compell great multitudes of people and hole countreys & nations, to forsake the feithe of Christe. Wherfore seinge he hath nother the keys of heuen, nor the key of diuine knoweledge, nor the key of feythe: I can perceyue none other, Mat. 5. Mar. 9. but that he is the vnsauery salt, wherof our sauiour Christe speketh in the gospell, whiche is no better worthe, but to be throwen out of the doores, and to be trodde vnder mens feete.

AND nowe to come to a conclusion of this lytell treatise: Where as it hath ben spokē of many and diuers, that it was a mery world before men spake of any suche mattiers, that is to witte, to haue any reformation amonge theim of the clergie, and before that men beganne to sette lyght the pope, and to call hym the bishop
of Rome: that is as wyse a sayenge and opinion, as this is of them that sey, sens the crienge downe of Galy halfpens, the lernynge of Duns neuer prosperedde, And also sens Tenterdyn steple was builded, Sandwiche hauen hath euer more decayed. But I praye you beholde, howe the fauourers of blynde abusion wolde fayne blowe abrode smokie and mystie reasons to darke & dymme mens eies with all. They sey it was merie before suche mattiers were moued, but they tell not what tyme it was, with whome, nor wherin it was merie. And if they meane, that the nobilitie and commons of this realme of Englande hadde more riches, and greatter plentie of foode and vitaile, and lyued in moche more welthe, and more at theyr hartis ease in lauful libertie: then lette them consider, that this was before the pope and his clergie were growen so great, so stronge
and myghty, and to so huge possessions and riches, as they welde at this daye: for before that tyme they preached the gospelle trewlye, they were meke and lowly spirited, and sufficiencye was to them abundaunce, they were charitable, they were milde and mercifull, and gaue good example, and men gladly folowed them, then reigned loue & liberalitie, then there was peace and vnitie, that causedde great plentie in euery place: But after they were ones endowed with possessions, and theyr myndes inordiatly drowned in them, and that Couetousnes beganne to crepe in amonge them, after that (I saye) folowed all mischiefe and miserie, all wretchednes and penurie: The pope, he polled a pace for his parte: yea whome wolde it not make right soroweful & heuy in harte to remembre, what ryches this cursed caytiffe ye pope hath polled out of this realme by the space
of these thre hundred yeres, ye within these. xl. yeres, or within these. xx. yeres? What pilleth he yerely? what myscheuous meanes doth he inuent and seke out, to robbe and spoyle vs of our welthe? What lawes hath he deuysed, what legations, what and howe many dyuerse courtes? What dispensations, what pencions out of abbeys exempt, what peter pens out of parishes, what reseruaciōs, what constitutions, what citations, what suspencions, what pardones, what kynde of cursynges, & blessynges & absolucions? what wyles, what gyles, what fraudes, what diuilishe deceytes and snares, are daylie couertly couched to catche coyne frome the peple? Oh good lorde, how the pope and his minysters dayly deuyse and practise to polle and pylle the people of this realme of theyr money? And yet I speke nothinge of the great vnquietnes and vexacion that many sely
soules haue, ouer and besides the losse of theyr goodes. He the moste vnhappy patrone and his, be the very cause of all our miserie, of all our scarsitie, and of all our vexacion and trowble. Who be the occasion and styrrers vppe of warre and stryffe in Christendome, but the pope and papistis? Looke who so lysteth, and he shall surely fynde, that the pope and his, to saue and kepe vppe styll theyr pompose and worldly state, haue alwey ben the inuenters of myschieffe and destruction of people, by theyr vngodlye instigations of pryncis to warre. Yea if the trouthe shulde be shewed of the great ruyne that hath rysen by them and theyr meanes, in Christendome, it wolde abhorre any man, were he neuer so partiall on the popis syde, eyther to rede or here it. But I woll lette that passe, I am right sory, that we shulde haue cause to shewe you so moche of hym as I
haue done, saue alonely I wolde all suche as be blynded, or be ignorant, shulde perceyue: that our moste gratious soueraygne lorde the kynge, is moste specially mouedde to do as he dothe, of his princely pitie and zele, that his highnes beareth to his true and louynge subiectes. Surely I say, this his tyrannie and pyllage in maner constraynethe the kynge his grace, to delyuer this his realme frō the captiuitie & bondage of the pope: and kepe within the sayd realme (for the welthe and safegard of the same) the great and huge somes of money, that were wont to runne to Rome.

¶ AND if it be not sufficient inough to persuade some of you, to se and so clerely to beholde, howe clene contrarie to the lawe of god the pope demeneth hym selfe, the which he is boūde in all that euer he may do, to folowe: then at the leeste wyse lette the great miserie and pore state, that this most
noble, and sometyme the moste florishynge realme of Christendome, is broughte into by the pollynge of the pope, moue and sturre you to stande styffely with our moste benigne and louynge souerayne lorde and prince, that is fully bente and gothe aboute to ridde his realme of this thraldom, and to restore and brynge it agayne out of pouertie to plentie, and frome rauyne to riches, and from trowble and greuous vexacion to quietnesse and reste, and so finally to al the former welthy state. Whervnto as good and trewe subiectes, with all youre hartis ye are also boūde by the lawes of god, his quarel beinge thus iuste, and he intendynge so greate a commoditie to all the realme. Accordyng as the holy apostol Paule sayth: Let Ro. 13. euery soule be subiecte to the high powers: for the powers that be, are ordeyned of god. So that he that resisteth the high power, resisteth the ordinance
of god. And they that resiste, seke theyr owne damnacion. Loke howe straytely the apostoll byndethe vs to the obedience of our prince: for in the same chapitre he nameth none other powers, but onely of princis.

And the holy apostol Peter likewise
• . Petri, 2. dothe commande vs to demeane ourselfes lyke lowely and obedient subiectes, whether it be to the kyng hymselfe, as to the moste chiefe and excellent of all, orels to the dukes and gouernours, that are sent by hym. And consequently he saythe: Honour the kynge. Nowe seinge that we be commanded by the holy scripture, to loue, to obey, and honour our prince, not only outwardly in bodies, but also inwardly in our hartes, withoute any dissimulacion or feynynge, and that bicause he is the minister of god, and dothe represent and occupie the place of god here in erthe: howe moche more then are we bounde to loue,
to obeye, to honoure, and ayde oure moste gratious prince, with all oure very hartis, whiche specially for our sakes taketh so great peyne, and that so diligentely dothe seke the meanes howe to ridde vs out of bondage, out of miserie, out of nede and vexacion, that we be broughte into by the couetousnes of the brybynge byshoppe of Rome (the whyche by that name of Pope polleth and pylfereth awey the riches of this realme) and that so moche myndeth to restore vs to all oure olde welthynes and libertie ageyne?

THVS ye se playnly proued to you by reason and auctorite of holy scripture, that we do none other wyse in oure tyme nowe, then oure wise and well lerned fore fathers dyd, though the tyme then wolde not suffre them to bringe to passe their well intended purpose. And it is shewed, that the olde holy doctours of Christis churche afferme, that nother custome, nor
vsage shulde be regarded, when the truthe ones appereth, but the truthe shulde be enbraced and folowed.

AND also it is wel proued that our prince & souerayne dothe it not nowe for or of any yuell wyl or displeasure: for they that eyther so thynke or sey, do thynke and sey vntrewly, and besydes that, in theyr so doinge, they greatly offende god. for it is writen: Gen 22. Eccl 10. Thou shalte not speke yuell by the prince of the people. And agayne it is writen: In thy thought thou shuldest not detracte the kinge.
AND it is like wyse manifestly proued, that thoughe the pope hadde as great auctoritie, as he vsurpeth and taketh on hym to haue: yet coulde he let no man to appele from hym.

AND it is lyke wyse proued, that the pope is neyther the catholyke holy churche of Christe, nor yet the heed of the same, but if he be a Christen man, he is the childe of our mother
the holy churche, and brother to euery christen man.

AND finally it is like wise shewed, that the miserie, nede, pouertie, and scacitie, that we be in, cometh all together by the pope and his meanes. Frome whome and whose captiuite, Christe delyuer vs, that boughte vs on a tree. Amen.
